html: I'm considering using the Git Hub Secrets on the infrastructure repository to manage the Ansible Vault Encryption Passphrase. Something I'll look into in the near future - would use your GitHub Personal Access Token (PAT) if we did that.

  2. it would help link the two - with infrastructure being private and close kept, while infrastructure-tracking being public and a known communication point with the wider world.

html:
The issue tracker for vegastrike.github.io should be specific to what's going on in with vegastrike.github.io; it shouldn't be concerned with our social accounts, etc.
infrastructure is very specific to managing the actual infrastructure; it's private (security), so folks can't directly file issues against it.
infrastructure-tracking isn't the website; we might be able to tweak its name as it tracks a lot of stuff - it's a public so folks can file issues against it and it can act as a place to discuss stuff.
So I kind of see infrastructure and infrastructure-tracking as a private/public partnership. If infrastructure became public then yes, infrastructure-tracking could go away... at least for the moment I'm not sure it can. May be as I learn more about GitHub secrets and how that might integrate that may change.
text:
The issue tracker for `vegastrike.github.io` should be specific to what's going on in with `vegastrike.github.io`; it shouldn't be concerned with our social accounts, etc.
infrastructure is very specific to managing the actual infrastructure; it's private (security), so folks can't directly file issues against it.
infrastructure-tracking isn't the website; we might be able to tweak its name as it tracks a lot of stuff - it's a public so folks can file issues against it and it can act as a place to discuss stuff.
So I kind of see infrastructure and infrastructure-tracking as a private/public partnership. If infrastructure became public then yes, infrastructure-tracking could go away... at least for the moment I'm not sure it can. May be as I learn more about GitHub secrets and how that might integrate that may change.

html: infrastructure being private is at least for the time being one of those "necessary evils"...if I can find a safe way to make it public without compromising our necessary secrets that we can't share publicly then I'll be all for it.
text: infrastructure being private is at least for the time being one of those "necessary evils"...if I can find a safe way to make it public without compromising our necessary secrets that we can't share publicly then I'll be all for it.

html: basically, the junk that is SystemD requires the tmpfs mount for /run to be at least 20MB; but the initramfs tools default to have it set to 10% of RAM. if RAM is too small, then you end up with too small a space and SystemD then refuses to restart services.
text: basically, the junk that is SystemD requires the tmpfs mount for /run to be at least 20MB; but the initramfs tools default to have it set to 10% of RAM. if RAM is too small, then you end up with too small a space and SystemD then refuses to restart services.

html: Version 132 of initramfs-tools-core and later added an option accessible via either the boot parameters (/etc/default/grub as initramfs.runsize) or via the tool's configuration (/etc/initramfs-tools/conf.d/* - add a file with the RUNSIZE parameter set)
text: Version 132 of initramfs-tools-core and later added an option accessible via either the boot parameters (/etc/default/grub as initramfs.runsize) or via the tool's configuration (/etc/initramfs-tools/conf.d/* - add a file with the RUNSIZE parameter set)

html: However, older versions require that /run have an entry in /etc/fstab to specify the size which SystemD is suppose to auto-detect and resize for you...only issue is that JournalD apparently may end up using up the whole space still because it configures itself based on the older, smaller disk.
text: However, older versions require that /run have an entry in /etc/fstab to specify the size which SystemD is suppose to auto-detect and resize for you...only issue is that JournalD apparently may end up using up the whole space still because it configures itself based on the older, smaller disk.

html:
okay - figured out the issues with libvirt:
(a) cleaning up Vagrant VMs deployed with one engine (VirtualBox) doesn't necessarily clean up all resources (general network bridge)
(b) libvirt doesn't give good errors; the VM was assigned too little memory (128MB); once I up'd it (512MB) it worked fine. Deb9 did fine with 128MB under VBox; but apparently Ubuntu Focal (20.04) wants more. Didn't play around to see what the minimal was. Oh - and found this by using virt-manager (the GUI for libvirt) to start and see the image boot up, which gave an "out of memory" error.
text:
okay - figured out the issues with libvirt:
(a) cleaning up Vagrant VMs deployed with one engine (VirtualBox) doesn't necessarily clean up all resources (general network bridge)
(b) libvirt doesn't give good errors; the VM was assigned too little memory (128MB); once I up'd it (512MB) it worked fine. Deb9 did fine with 128MB under VBox; but apparently Ubuntu Focal (20.04) wants more. Didn't play around to see what the minimal was. Oh - and found this by using `virt-manager` (the GUI for libvirt) to start and see the image boot up, which gave an "out of memory" error.

html: took a look at the spamassassin issue...seems to be well known; solution might be modifying the systemd config for spamassassin...just got to get it working correctly - namely, the command times out when restarting spamassassin but it does actually restart properly so need to set a longer timeout period.
text: took a look at the spamassassin issue...seems to be well known; solution might be modifying the systemd config for spamassassin...just got to get it working correctly - namely, the command times out when restarting spamassassin but it does actually restart properly so need to set a longer timeout period.

html: I think it's also related to spamassassin, amavis, and clamav each taking up 30% of the VM - even a vagrant ssh into the system takes a long time to gain access at times; so it's probably something related to local resources which should be resolved in the cloud VM or other systems that have more resources for the VM itself too.

html: Just FYI - @nabaco started https://opencollective.com/vega-strike and we've since built up about $120 in reserves. We probably should start thinking about how it should be responsibly spent. When we started it I was thinking of a $5/month DO server on our DO account (which presently is there but doesn't have any systems associated with it). It's been on my mind...it would be good if we were able to run a server or two in a way that didn't deplete the funds - e.g fit within the monthly contributions - so that we had a little buffer should regular contributors drop. So please reach out to me... @www2000 we can help some with your server if you like.
